bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, May 30, 1942

div1.p: Hench requests that Kellogg invite Truby to an upcoming event concerning the Cornwell paintings. He invites Kellogg to a banquet at which Hench will give a speech on the conquest of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, May 30, 1942

opener.dateline:
May 30, 1942 Mr. George Kellogg
41 East 42nd Street
New York, N. Y.

div1.p:
Mrs. Hench and I will certainly be at the luncheon in Atlantic City on
June 8. As I may have written you, my associate and I are giving a paper at
the meeting of the American Rheumatism that same day and ours is the last one in
the morning. I have told the chairman of our desire to go to your luncheon and
he has promised to hurry things along so that our meeting will not be dragged out.

I have just received a formal invitation and also a nice letter from Mr.
Law, which I am answering. Would you kindly send a formal invitation to General
Truby, our yellow fever friend? He is at 1831 Summit Place, N.W., Washington, D.C.
and I am so anxious that he come down to the unveiling of your other painting.

Monday evening, at the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall, is to be the banquet of the
American Rheumatism Association, at which time I am to give my after dinner illus-
trated talk on the conquest of yellow fever. I hope that Truby can be there. Would
you like to sit in on it? I imagine you will be pretty tired by that time and ready
to go out and get tight. Also you are probably quite fed up on the yellow fever
business although you have never heard me give the thing formally and in this
illustrated fashion. This is merely a round-about way of inviting you to be my
guest at this banquet if you should care to come.

I am assuming that this letter to you and my personal letter to Mr. Law
constitute a formal acceptance of the invitation to your luncheon.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
